translated: Points of Controversy
The Fifty on Refutation
The Seventeenth Chapter

analyzed: atthi araha topuñña upacaya uti kathā
translated: The Discussion on Whether Merit Increases for an Arahant
“Is there an increase of merit for an Arahant?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: atthi arahataḥ a puñña upacayo ti
translated: “Is there an increase of demerit for an Arahant?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: na atthi arahataḥ a puñña upacayo ti
translated: “Is there no increase of demerit for an Arahant?”
“Yes.”
“Is there no increase of merit for an Arahant?”
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye faculty and the eye consciousness?” …
“Is there an increase of merit for an Arahant?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Arahā puññābhisaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharoti, āneñjābhisaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkharoti, gatisaṁvattaniyaṁ
analyzed: āmantā  arahā puñña abhisaṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti āneñja abhisaṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti gati savattaniya
translated: “Yes.”

original: kammaṁ karoti, bhavasaṁvattaniyaṁ kammaṁ karoti, issariyasaṁvattaniyaṁ kammaṁ karoti,🔽adhipaccasaṁvattaniyaṁ kammaṁ karoti, mahābhogasaṁvattaniyaṁ kammaṁ karoti, mahāparivārasaṁvattaniyaṁ
analyzed: kammam karoti bhava savattaniyam kammam karoti issariya savattaniyam kammam karoti  adhipacca savattaniyam kammam karoti mahā bhoga savattaniyam kammam karoti mahā parivāra savattaniya
translated: “An Arahant performs a meritorious volitional formation, a desireless volitional formation, an action that leads to destiny, an action that leads to becoming, an action that leads to sovereignty,🔽an action that leads to predominance, an action that leads to great influence, an action that leads to great wealth, an action that leads to a great retinue,

original: kammaṁ karoti, devasobhagyasaṁvattaniyaṁ kammaṁ karoti, manussasobhagyasaṁvattaniyaṁ kammaṁ karotīti?
analyzed: kammam karoti deva sobhagya savattaniyam kammam karoti manussa sobhagya savattaniyam kammam karoti iti
translated: an action that leads to good luck in the heavens, an action that leads to good luck among human beings?”🔽“Yes.”
“That is not so,” he said.
“Is there an accumulation of merit for one who is an arahant?”
“Yes.”
“Does one who is an arahant accumulate?”
“That is not so,” he said.
“Does one who is an arahant diminish?”

analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe pe  arahā pajahati iti pe
translated: “That is not so,” he said.🔽“Does one who is an arahant abandon?”

analyzed: arahāḥ upādiyati iti pe  arahāḥ visineti iti pe
translated: “Does one who is an arahant cling?”🔽“Does one who is an arahant throw away?”

analyzed: arahāḥ ussineti iti pe  arahāḥ vidhūpa iti iti pe
translated: “Does one who is an arahant throw out?”🔽“Does one who is an arahant fan out?”
“Does one who is an arahant fan out and then gather in?”
“That is not so,” he said.

original: nanu arahā nevācināti na apacināti apacinitvā ṭhitoti?
analyzed: nanu arahā na iva ācināti na apacināti apacinitvā
translated: “But, friend, doesn’t one who is an arahant neither accumulate nor diminish, but stands having accumulated and diminished?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci arahā nevācināti nāpacināti apacinitvā ṭhito, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: āmantā  hañci arahā na iva ācināti na apacināti apacinitvā ṭhitaḥ no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Yes.”
“Then it is not right to say that ‘There is an accumulation of merit for one who is an arahant.’

original: Nanu arahā neva pajahati na upādiyati pajahitvā ṭhito, neva visineti na ussineti visinetvā ṭhito, neva vidhūpeti na sandhūpeti vidhūpetvā ṭhitoti?
analyzed: nanu arahā na iva pajahati na upādiyati pajahitvā ṭhitaḥ na iva visineti na ussineti visinetvā ṭhitaḥ na iva vidhūpeti na sandhūpeti vidhūpetvā ṭhitaḥ uti
translated: “But, friend, doesn’t one who is an arahant neither abandon nor cling, but stands having abandoned and clung? Doesn’t he neither throw away nor throw out, but stands having thrown away and thrown out? Doesn’t he neither fan out nor fan out and then gather in, but stands having fanned out and fanned out and then gathered in?”
“Yes.”

original: Hañci arahā neva vidhūpeti na sandhūpeti vidhūpetvā ṭhito, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci arahā na iva vidhūpeti na sandhūpeti vidhūpetvā ṭhitaḥ no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Well then, it seems the perfected one neither fans the fire nor puts out the fire, but stands having fanned it out. But it’s not right to say that
there’s an increase of merit for the perfected one.”
“There’s no increase of merit for the perfected one?”
“Yes.”
“Would a perfected one give a gift?”
“Yes.”

original: Hañci arahā dānaṁ dadeyya, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci arahā dānam dadeyya no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Well then, it seems a perfected one would give a gift, and it’s not right to say that

analyzed: na atthi arahato puññūpacayo ti  arahā cīvaram dadeyya pe
translated: there’s no increase of merit for the perfected one.”🔽“Would a perfected one give a robe?”🔽“Would a perfected one give almsfood?”

analyzed: piṇḍapātam dadeyya  senāsanam dadeyya  gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāram dadeyya
translated: “Would a perfected one give a dwelling?”🔽“Would a perfected one give medicine when sick?”🔽“Would a perfected one give fresh produce?”

analyzed: khādanīyam dadeyya  bhojanīyam dadeyya  pānīyam dadeyya
translated: “Would a perfected one give cooked food?”🔽“Would a perfected one give water?”🔽“Would a perfected one worship a shrine?”

original: cetiyaṁ vandeyya …🔽cetiye mālaṁ āropeyya …🔽gandhaṁ āropeyya …🔽vilepanaṁ āropeyya …pe…
analyzed: cetiyam vandeyya  cetiye mālam āropeyya  gandham āropeyya  vilepanam āropeyya pe
translated: “Would a perfected one hang a garland on a shrine?”🔽“Would a perfected one apply perfume to a shrine?”🔽“Would a perfected one apply ointment to a shrine?”
“Would a perfected one circumambulate a shrine while keeping it to one’s right?”
“Yes.”

original: Hañci arahā cetiyaṁ abhidakkhiṇaṁ kareyya, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci arahā cetiyam abhidakkhiṇam kareyya no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “Well then, it seems a perfected one would circumambulate a shrine while keeping it to one’s right, and it’s not right to say that
there’s no increase of merit for the perfected one.”

analyzed: atthi arahato puñña upacayaḥ ti kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: Discussion of whether there is fresh merit for one who is an Arahant is ended.
